Award.AwardTitle: Research Initiation Grant: Student-directed differentiated learning in college-level engineering education

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
Differentiated learning, i.e. adjusting educational material delivery according to the strengths and weaknesses of each student, has gained traction in K-12 education, but not in higher education. Part of the reason is the significant workload imposed on the instructor, who needs to design material delivery on an individual basis. While this is reasonable for younger children, higher education students are adults that need to take charge of their own educational pathway, especially in view of the need for them to sustain life-long education efforts. In this study, we investigate tools and methodologies that support students into choosing their own individualized study plan, including frequent feedback though formative homework assignments, homeworks that offer options at different levels of challenge, and online reference video libraries. This aims at providing additional support to students with lower readiness levels, while still offering challenging tasks to students with stronger backgrounds. We expect this approach to help increase retention and success rates for students of varied educational background and possibly socio-economic status, while at the same time providing a more stimulating experience for students with higher readiness levels. While the proposed research is mainly directed towards a traditional classroom-based course, the student-driven approach adopted makes it relevant to environments where there is a need for student-initiated instruction plan choices, such as MOOCs and life-long learning.

The aim of this project it twofold. First, we intend to develop techniques for creating a framework for student-directed differentiated instruction material for adult learners. For this part, we investigate a general framework of combined formative assignments, tiered homeworks and a tiered reference video library. Elements of this plan include formative assessment, which provides information on student readiness levels in order to help with subsequent decisions; tiered homework menus to help students practice and develop skills at the level they perceive as most appropriate; and a library of online video material aimed at creating customized recitation sessions based at what students think they need most help with. Our interest is both on how to optimally develop these tools, and how to combine them within course design. Second, we investigate the factors that influence student decisions when creating an individualized study plan within this framework. The main focus of this research is to analyze how engineering students use information from the formative assessment together with their perception of their readiness level in order to make choices, and how this affects their overall learning experience and its outcomes.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A challenge faced by instructors in college-level engineering education are different readiness levels in students, especially in freshmen and sophomore courses. Students come from different high schools, and have followed different curricula; this results in variations in the completeness and rigor of academic backgrounds when entering an engineering program. While such differences have been addressed at the K-12 level using the concept of differentiated learning, little is known about approaches that adapt to individual students’ needs at the college level.

In this project, we examined two different teaching interventions. The first one is the introduction of tiered homework assignments, i.e. assignments that comprise a menu of problems at different levels, ranging from simpler, procedural exercises to more challenging design-level ones, appropriately weighted grade-wise for their difficulty, and asking the students to choose enough problems to add to a sum of points. Our results examining the choices of the students indicate that they try to stay within their comfort level; however, offering a choice that could adapt to their perceived needs improved overall grades, and exposure to more complicated problems, even if they chose not to solve them, made them more amenable to complex problems when they saw similar ones in the future.

The second intervention was the introduction of a video library of problem solutions. We assumed that students that felt they needed extra support would choose to watch the material, while we would avoid overwhelming students that did not need additional explanations. We selected video as a means of delivery because it complements traditional written classroom material, appealing to visual and audio learners; and because it is difficult to skim compared to written material. Contrary to our expectations, the majority of the students chose to watch all the videos, without differentiation from the readiness levels. This may indicate that there may be a need for additional time spent providing explanations and support that such videos could provide a substitute for. Feedback from the students pointed to the ability to rewind, and the fact that without the time pressure of a classroom lecture, more detailed explanations were given, as the main advantages of this type of delivery.

While providing additional support and adaptation was beneficial for the students, the feasibility of this approach also depends on the additional workload for the instructor. During this project, we worked on developing best practices and understanding of priorities. While the workload involved in designing such a teaching approach is more than that of a conventional classroom delivery, it is an approach that can be adapted gradually, especially if the same instructor teaches a course over several semesters. Furthermore, while there is an upfront workload, as for example in the case of video development, the material can be reused over subsequent semesters.

Overall, we believe that the interventions presented provide tools that can help adapt course delivery to the individual student needs while letting the student make the choice on how to adapt the material. At a college-level course, this can help students either succeed at courses that may be challenging for their readiness levels, or keep the interest of students at higher readiness levels that are looking for a challenge, thereby enhancing the educational experience of both. However, helping students learn how to make such choices will be vital for their professional career later on, when continuing education, often provided through online courses, becomes indispensable in order to gain vital job skills. We believe that knowledge learned in how to design adaptive courses can help improve continuing education options.
